qas.question: French comics are also known as what?
When is the term comics considered singular rather than plural?

answers.text: when it refers to the medium

qas.question: The historical aspect of cartooning can be applied to mass reproduction or what?
Some experts believe comics is a combination of what two things?
French comics are not known as what?

plausible_answers.text: when it refers to the medium

qas.question: When is the term comics considered multiple rather than plural?
The non-historical aspect of cartooning can be applied to mass reproduction or what?
No experts believe comics is a combination of what two things?
What are Japanese comics never called?

context: The English term comics is used as a singular noun <a1_0><b6_0>when it refers to the medium<b6_0/><a1_0/> and a plural when referring to particular instances, such as individual strips or comic books. Though the term derives from the humorous (or comic) work that predominated in early American newspaper comic strips, it has become standard also for non-humorous works. It is common in English to refer to the comics of different cultures by the terms used in their original languages, such as <a4_0><b9_0>manga<b9_0/><a4_0/> for Japanese comics, or <a0_0><b5_0>bandes dessinées<b5_0/><a0_0/> for French-language comics. There is no consensus amongst theorists and historians on a definition of comics; some emphasize the combination of <a3_0><b8_0>images and text<b8_0/><a3_0/>, some sequentiality or other image relations, and others historical aspects such as mass reproduction or the use of <a2_0><b7_0>recurring characters<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The increasing cross-pollination of concepts from different comics cultures and eras has further made definition difficult.
